The steady murmur of foreign languages as they are being spoken all around you will be a delightful change from your everyday, and you can soak in the breathtaking views of an endless stretch of white sand beach against the vibrant metropolitan backdrop of Tel Aviv before retiring to your luxurious accommodation for the evening.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Journey to Kabbalah's Birthplace and Privately Tour a Boutique Winery
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy breakfast at your hotel before meeting your private driver in the lobby for your transfer to the mystical city of Safed. Also known as Tzfat or the Blue City, Safed is the birthplace of the esoteric teachings of Kabbalah in the Jewish faith. You will arrive at your boutique hotel in the heart of Safed’s famed Artist Colony and take in glorious mountaintop views from beautiful blue buildings that overlook a majority of this immaculate city. You will meet your guide in the lobby for a private city tour of Safed, stopping into the city’s most notable art galleries and meeting many local artists. Afterward, you will delight in a Kabbalistic ritual that will be led by one of Safed’s most distinguished rabbis. Leaving the city, you will be transferred by private coach through the luscious landscapes of the Golan Heights, where you can bask in the beauty of the region’s rivers, streams, vineyards, and fields. You will arrive at Mount Bental, which is a remarkable overlook of Syria across the Israeli border. Here, you will have the opportunity to learn a bit about the politics of the region before moving on to enjoy a specially curated tour of one of the Golan Heights’ renowned boutique wineries. Lastly, you will delight in the opportunity to taste some of the country’s finest wines as you gaze over the gorgeous greenery of the Golan.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Visit Haifa's Baha'i Gardens and Delight in Traditional Druze Hospitality
dayInfo.description: Awaken once again in the picturesque city of Safed and prepare for your private transfer to the charming port city of Haifa. Standing at the entrance to the striking Baha’i gardens, you will be amazed at the magnificent, panoramic view over the entire city. As you descend into the gardens, your expert guide will offer insight into the fascinating Baha’i faith. At the base of the gardens, you will have time to explore Haifa’s quaint German Colony, stopping into its many charming shops, restaurants, and cafes at your guide’s suggestion before indulging a classic Israeli snack of pita bread, hummus, and tahini. You can bask in the serenity of the calm Haifa morning while you snack on your Israeli delicacies. Moving on, your private driver will transfer you to the lovely mountain town of Isfiya, which is home to one of Israel’s thriving Druze communities. Here, you will have the opportunity to learn about the captivating culture and traditions of the Druze people who are known for their warm hospitality and delicious food. You can savor a typical lunch as you dine with a local Druze family in their home. Walking through the winding streets of the Druze village, you can stop to admire the stunning view from the mountaintop on which you stand before returning with your guide to Safed where you can enjoy the evening of exploring at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Negev – Explore Masada, the Dead Sea, and Ride a Camel Through the Desert
dayInfo.description: You will need an early start this morning as you wake before the sun for your private transfer to the remarkable Masada Fortress. You will ascend the world-famous fortress via cable car and arrive just in time to view the stunning sunrise over the extraordinary Dead Sea. Here, you will discover the history of Masada and learn how it has become a symbol of triumph and empowerment for the Israeli people. Afterward, you will descend by cable car and transfer to one of the illustrious beaches of the Dead Sea. Finally, you will be able to float weightlessly in the Sea’s salinized waters and cover yourself in the region’s natural mineral mud, which is famous for its healing properties. You will continue your day with a transfer to the boundless Negev Desert. Here, you will enjoy a thrilling camel ride, which will be complete with breathtaking views of the vast desert, before returning to the exotic Bedouin village. Here, you will be greeted by members of this nomadic tribe who will offer you delectable sweet tea, which is customary of Bedouin culture. They will also provide you with a traditional meal and show of music and dance. After being immersed in the warmth of Bedouin hospitality, you can retire to your desert “glampsite” where you will spend the night in complete luxury under an endless sky of glittering stars.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Discover Jerusalem's New City and Privately Tour Yad Vashem
dayInfo.description: Today, you will enjoy your final breakfast at the Bedouin tents before boarding your private transfer to the wonderful city of Jerusalem. You will arrive at your luxurious hotel that overlooks the majestic Old City to freshen up before you make your way to the world-renowned Yad Vashem museum, which is the World Holocaust Remembrance Center. Here, you will uncover the somber history of the Holocaust on a private tour that will be led by an expert guide. You will learn how this calamitous event shaped the cultural identity of this resilient country before walking through the eerie Children’s Memorial as you are guided by candlelight with the chilling murmur of names being read aloud. This experience will be sure to evoke an ineffable mood of grief and wonder. Moving forward on a lighter note, your guide will transfer you to the heart of Jerusalem’s New City, where you will explore the lively Ben Yehuda Street. Strolling along the New City’s main drag, you will be impressed by live music and street performers before taking time to stop into the many shops that sell locally crafted artifacts. You can take in the sights and sounds of this cheerful area, enjoy dinner here at one of the many bustling bars and restaurants, and experience daily life in Jerusalem as it really is.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Unearth the Treasures of the Old City and Visit the Mount of Olives
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will be provided with a traditional Israeli breakfast at your opulent hotel before meeting your guide in the lobby to embark on today’s activities. You will begin at the Mount of Olives, where you will delight in a phenomenal panoramic view over the town of Jerusalem. From the thick stone steps of the overlook, you can notice the famous golden Dome of the Rock as it glistens in the distance. A gentle breeze may rustle against your face, which will be a welcoming contrast to the warmth of the Mediterranean sun. As you look out over the vast expanse of the city, you can feel the weight of thousands of years of history as it eagerly waits to unveil its secrets. You will continue to enter the heart of the Old City. Here, you will delight in a private tour of all four religious quarters, stopping for souvenirs in the Muslim Quarter and strolling through the charming, cobblestoned streets to arrive at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, which is one of Christianity’s holiest sites. Here, you will learn of its history and religious relevance from your expert guide, and as you enter the Jewish Quarter, you should prepare to approach the monumental Wailing Wall. You can reach out to stick a note that you have written into the aching cracks of the wall. You will be alongside worshippers, locals, and tourists from every corner of the Earth who have made their way to this very spot. After your tour that is sure to have you marveling at all the history that you have uncovered today, you will be returned to your luxurious accommodation, where you will have the rest of the evening to spend at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Privately Tour the Israel Museum and Explore the Bustling Shuk
dayInfo.description: After breakfast today, you will begin your excursion with a transfer to the world-renowned Israel Museum. Here, you will be provided with a private tour of the museum to discover some of Israel’s most revered cultural treasures such as the recently uncovered Dead Sea Scrolls and the Second Temple Model, which models a complete version of Jerusalem before the Great Revolt against Roman Rule. You can also enjoy the museum’s Archeological Tel, which details Israel’s many archeological digs throughout history, before marveling at the many other exhibits that are held within this extensive museum. Leaving the Israel Museum, your private driver will transfer you to Jerusalem’s infamous Shuk, which is also known as the Mahane Yehuda Market. Here, you can discover the excitement of one of the cornerstones of Middle Eastern culture as you traverse the market like a local, haggling for the best prices and stopping to sample traditional delicacies. From the sweet taste of chocolate babka to the rich aroma of Israeli spices, you can fully immerse yourself in the buzz of the bustling Shuk. You can also sample a juicy Israeli date among a plethora of other delicacies, letting the luscious flavor wash over your tongue. You will be amazed at the bright colors of endless fruit and vegetable stands in addition to the exotic array of traditional Jewish baked goods, which can be yours for only a handful of Shekels.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Spend the Morning in Jerusalem and Head for Home
dayInfo.description: Today will be your final morning in Jerusalem, and as you explore the Old City at your leisure, you can stroll through the ancient streets and stop at a charming cafe to soak in your last moments in the Holy Land. As you look around at your travel companions, you cannot help but reminisce on your wonderful trip thus far. As you reminisce through all that you have seen and experienced over the course of these 10-days, you will realize that this has been your trip of a lifetime and an experience that you will never forget. You will return to your hotel to gather your belongings to meet your private driver for your transfer to the airport and your journey home.

tourName: Israel with Kids Tour: A Family Friendly Exploration
generalInfo: Dig into the past and relish modern thrills during your customizable family friendly tour of Israel. The turquoise hues of the Mediterranean Sea spread across the western horizon. Secret tunnels and narrow alleys contain insight into the Roman occupation and Byzantine chapels. Desert fortresses provide unparalleled views of orchards and vineyards sprouting from the oases. Feel buoyant in the waters of the Dead Sea and enjoy the grainy sand at your fingertips during an archaeological excavation. From antique markets in Jerusalem to the vibrant streets of Tel Aviv, the family can indulge in an assortment of marvels during your unforgettable adventure in Israel.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – A Family Awakening
dayInfo.description: The beaches of Tel Aviv glisten in the sunlight. Turquoise waters of the Mediterranean Sea lap against the shoreline. Locals walk along the aisles of the Carmel Market in search of fresh produce, from radishes to raspberries. The scent of the sea drifts through the streets and blends with the strong aroma of coffee emanating from the chic cafes. Your flight lands at Ben Gurion International Airport, where your private transfer meets the family upon arrival. The city bustles with contemporary style and enticing ambiance. Beachgoers play matkot , a popular paddle ball game often referred to as the Israeli national sport, on the sand. The creamy antique stones of Jaffa, one of the oldest existing ports in the world, shimmer with hints of gold. After settling into the luxuries of your hotel, the family steps out with your guide for an introductory walking tour of the city. You make your way to the promenade to experience the life around the wooden decks of the Tel Aviv Port. Locals ride bikes, stroll, and jog along the walkways overlooking the cobalt hues of the Mediterranean. Seagulls perch on the edges of the bordering buildings. Restaurants fill their outdoor decks with couples and friends eager to enjoy the view and a sampling of tomato and cucumber salad. The promenade extends for nine miles, connecting Tel Aviv’s Hatzuk Beach in the north to Jaffa in the south. Men cast their fishing lines into the water and relax as they wait for the fish to bite. The kids watch with awe as they point out a world of similarities and differences, wrapping their minds around the culture to which they are being introduced.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – In with the Old and New
dayInfo.description: In the morning, locals walk along the cobbled roads of Shenkin Street. Coffee shops and restaurants open their doors to the aromas of fresh coffee and simmering shakshuka , a traditional Middle Eastern breakfast of egg and vegetables cooked in tomato sauce. The boutique windows display collections of vintage and handmade chic garments, from pants to scarves. The gold-sand beaches fill with locals and visitors from around the world soaking up the morning sun. Your guide meets the family at the hotel, ready to lead you on a remarkable tour of Tel Aviv, beginning with a visit to Independence Hall. At the Palmach Museum, the family has an introduction into the underground defense organization known as the Haganah , which was established as a strike force before Israel’s founding. The gold and textured stone flickers with gilded hues. A sycamore tree adds a refreshing fragrance to the air. The exhibits offer a three-dimensional immersion into the Palmach legacy. The organization helped defend pre-Israel Palestine from the Nazi invasion during World War II and brought thousands of refugees from Europe following the war. The kids fill with excitement to venture underground into an old grotto. A documentary of the Palmach projects onto the wall for a unique experience involving the whole family. In the afternoon, you venture to Old Jaffa, one of the oldest remaining ports in the world, with a history spanning more than 7,000 years. A minaret stands like a lighthouse on a hill. Your guide explains that the 18th-century structure was erected using columns from the Roman city of Caesarea.

dayInfo.title: Rosh Hanikra – Reconstructing History
dayInfo.description: In the morning, sailboats glide over the Mediterranean in the distance and fishermen return to the promenade, keen on casting their lines into the turquoise water. After breakfast, your guide leads the family out of Tel Aviv and along the coastal plains. The Roman city of Caesarea continues to rise out of the grassland. The scent of herbaceous soil blends into the coastal breeze. The kids remind you of the minaret at Jaffa, which used the stones taken from the ancient Roman city. The architects used concrete in the 1st century BCE to erect a harbor with breakwaters. The kids marvel at the Herodian Amphitheatre. Your guide tells stories of the chariot races and gladiatorial games that once took place amidst the 820-foot long plaza. Lions and crocodiles battled the gladiators with up to 10,000 spectators cheering. In the afternoon, you reach the Rosh Hanikra Grottoes, located on the outskirts of Kibbutz Rosh Hanikra. Fishermen stand on protruding flat rocks and cast their lines into the splashing sea. The cliffs shimmer with white stone. Rosh Hanikra represents the only point in Israel at which the sea meets the cliffs, located at the country’s northwestern tip. The sea changes from turquoise to sapphire. You can hear the small waves wading against the boulders below. A scenic cable car takes the family down to the walking paths at the heart of the cliffs. The sea caves contain smooth walls with natural indentations marked by rainwater opening the bedrock. The tunnels reach a length of more than 650 feet with interconnecting segments. The sunlight casts an iridescent shimmer through the grottoes, easily enchanting the entire family.

dayInfo.title: Rosh Hanikra – On the Creative Trail
dayInfo.description: In the morning, you make your way to the ancient town of Tzfat, also known as Safed. Cobblestone streets bisect antique structures. The aroma of delicious falafel emanates from the open doors of the cafes. Small tables stand atop the antique stones, allowing patrons to enjoy watching passersby. The town stands at an altitude of nearly 3,000 feet above sea level and has been considered one of the four holiest sites of Judaism since the 16th century. The Sephardic Ari Synagogue was established in the 16th century and remains Safed’s oldest known synagogue. A small room stands to the left of the bimah , a raised platform. Candles flicker with light, representing the countless hours the practitioner known as the Holy Ari spent studying mystical texts. The synagogue and the small room contain a majestic ambiance embellished with the creative sensibilities of the town’s artist colony. You continue to the Manara Cliffs to ride the cable car for 6,350 feet, the longest in Israel. The scenic ride encompasses the surrounding valley. Lush farms glow emerald against the staggering edges of the cliff. Cypress trees intersperse the structures of the town below.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Along for the Thrilling Ride
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the aroma of olive orchards and cypress trees fills the air, accompanying the refreshing scent of freshly brewed coffee. After breakfast, the family steps aboard a four-wheel drive jeep, ready to ride through the Golan Heights. The terrain fluctuates between verdant green and wildflowers to basalt boulders and deep canyons. Orchards and vineyards sprout up near springs, and the volcanic plateau turns dry and tan in the summer months. You reach Nimrod Fortress; a 13th-century edifice erected to protect the road connecting Tyre to Damascus. A narrow ridge reaches upwards of nearly 2,675 feet above sea level on the slopes of Mount Hermon. The kids are awestruck at the size of the walls adorning the remote mountain terrain. The fortifications reach a length of more than 1,300 feet and a width of nearly 500 feet. Lush tufts and bushes texture the tan mountain ridges. Stone archways continue to frame the walkways meandering through the fortress. The family has a dramatic view of the forested valleys separating the Golan Heights from Mount Herman leading to the Lebanon border. The kids listen with intent to the history of the fortress, from its destruction by the Mongols to the impressive 13th-century hall. You run your fingers over the smooth stones framing the angled archer slits in the Northern Tower to fully realize the preserved nature of history. In the afternoon, you venture to Beit She’an to view a working archeological dig.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Adventures in the Old City
dayInfo.description: The morning light washes over the mixture of cobblestones trees and palm trees. The city shimmers with golden hues spreading along the surrounding hills. The Old City is one of the world’s leading pilgrimage destinations due to its impressive collection of sacred relics, structures, and living history. After breakfast, the family steps back in time to the Roman Empire by following your guide through the Cardo Maximus, one of the main streets used in Roman and Byzantine times. The street extends to a length of more than 650 feet located nearly 20 feet below the contemporary city. Shops once ran along the side of the road, flanked by columns supporting an awning. The small Burnt House Museum immediately fascinates the family through its display of a Herodian period home. The kids point out the exhibited artifacts of Roman coins amongst the protected remnants of the stone walls. You gain a vivid picture of Jewish history up to 70 BCE when the Romans sacked the city. The Wailing Wall captivates you and the kids as it continues to embody the Second Temple. The sounds of the surrounding plaza fade to the melodic prayers and chants visitors say while visiting the nearly 160-foot long partition. Small notes stick out from between the cracks of the walls, each containing a secret prayer someone left. The family takes the time to write their prayers on a sliver of paper before folding the note and placing it between the ancient stones.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Taking to the New Roads
dayInfo.description: Jerusalem’s Old City captivates visitors from around the world and maintains a strong connection to the three major monotheistic religions. The domes of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre reflect the morning light. Locals make their way to the bustling aisles of the Mahane Yehuda Market to find fresh produce and celebrated food stalls. The aromas of za’atar and freshly squeezed lemon drift through the marketplace, accompanying the scent of nutty baklava. The majesty of Old Jerusalem lingers at breakfast before the family ventures out to explore the splendors of the New City on a guided tour, beginning at the Herzl Museum. Mount Herzl commemorates Theodor Herzl, the founder of Zionism. You walk through a reconstruction of Herzl’s library and study located near the museum’s main entrance before following the walkway to view the freestanding sarcophagus. The interactive museum contains audio-visual presentations of Herzl’s life interwoven with photos, allowing for an immersive look into the activist’s vision. After visiting the Holocaust Memorial of Yad Vashem, your guide leads you through the bustling aisles of Mahane Yehuda for a more encompassing experience. Large sacks contain various spices offering a rich collection of aromas, from cardamom to dried fennel and cinnamon. The kids marvel at the maze-like walkways blending the sounds of the city with the aromas of mouthwatering restaurants, bright produce, and active shopkeepers calling out to passersby.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Dipping into the Dead Sea
dayInfo.description: At noon, the bells from the Church of the Holy Sepulchre chime against the movement of Jerusalem. Byzantine mosaics decorate hidden churches along the Armenian Quarter. Narrow lanes lead to some of Jerusalem’s oldest chapels, including the 12th-century chapel of St. Mark’s. After breakfast, your guide meets the family at the hotel and escorts you to the banks of the Dead Sea at the Ein Gedi Spa. The region celebrates the healing properties the water, air, sun, and soil. Heated pools along the property contain the local sulfur water, known for helping skin ailments and soothing the body. The kids take turns rubbing the mud on their arms and legs, allowing the rich nutrients to coat their skin. The soil dries and crusts in the desert’s natural heat. You walk down to the lapping water of the Dead Sea, located at the earth’s lowest elevation on land, at more than 1,400 feet below sea level. The sea reaches a depth of nearly 1,000 feet and contains a high salinity rate. Mounds of salt sporadically assemble along the lakeshore, resembling pockets of snow. The family eases into the refreshing water, washing away the mud on their skin. You lounge in the sea and let the rich salt content keep you afloat on the water’s surface.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – The Mountains of Judea
dayInfo.description: Today the family ventures to the Ayalon Institute located in Rehovot. The museum is located in a restored bullet factory opened in 1945 under the guise of a regular kibbutz, an area utilized for farming. The factory is located more than 25 feet underground. The subterranean character keeps the room cool amidst the desert heat. Workers produced 9mm bullets for Palmach fighters in complete secrecy until 1948. Your guide leads you through the reconstructed dining room and halls to offer insight into how those working the factory lived at the time. Above ground, the aroma of eucalyptus emanates from the lush groves. The family continues to Beit Guvrin National Park, the ancestral home of King Herod. Underground labyrinths crisscross the landscape to connect the tunnels to subterranean rooms. Remnants of ancient olive oil production and weaving installations reflect Hellenistic settlements. The family has a hands-on archaeological excursion to learn about the history of the region and the daily work of a real-life archaeologist. Step into the field, passing between areas segmented with tape. The family digs into the soft soil using small shovels and brushes in search of pottery shards and elements of life in the region. The kids focus on pouring sand into the provided buckets before sifting through the soil. The archaeologists pick the pieces of what was once a complete vase.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – A Glance at Israel
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the 19th-century narrow, winding lanes of the Nachlaot District fill with locals making their way to work. The preserved historical houses frame the walkways and antique synagogues, including Ades Synagogue on Shilo Street. The Syrian Jewish community erected the edifice at the turn of the 20th century in the traditional Middle Eastern architectural style. Chandeliers dangle from the high ceilings and wooden benches face the central dais. The temple ark covers the entire eastern wall. Your guide leads you on a half-day tour of the newer districts of the city, including the Israel Museum. The galleries exhibit more than 500,000 artifacts, including the celebrated Dead Sea Scrolls. The kids marvel at the unique, tattered documents after learning the scrolls were written between the 1st and 2nd centuries BCE. You take note of the ancient calligraphy, in which each word holds an elegant shape all on its own. After exploring the Christian Quarter, your private transfer meets you, ready to escort the family to Ben Gurion International Airport. You could extend your family vacation and take the time to visit Eilat located on the shores of the Red Sea, along with wandering the canyons and captivating cliffs of Petra in Jordan.

tourName: Romance in the Holy Land: 10-Day Tour of Israel
placesVisited: Jerusalem, Negev Desert, Eilat, Dead Sea, Tel Aviv, Jaffa, Safed
generalInfo: As you stroll along Tel Aviv’s sunny promenade hand in hand with your partner, you can gaze out over the glittering Mediterranean Sea, basking in the sun’s rays as they reflect upon your face. Approaching the remarkable Wailing Wall, you slide your hand-written note between its ancient cracks, savoring the beauty of the meaningful moment. These are just some of the many wonderful experiences that you will experience on your romantic, 10-day tour of Israel. If you are seeking to discover how thousands of years of history have been consolidated effortlessly with the cultures of modern-day, then you and your partner will love experiencing this enchanting country together.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Arrive in Jerusalem and Explore the Lively New City
dayInfo.description: Home to the holiest sites of some of the world’s most prominent religions and one of the globe’s most modern countries in the fields of science and technology, Israel has endless treasures to discover. You will arrive at Tel Aviv’s Ben Gurion Airport and be met by your private driver at the baggage claim to prepare for your transfer to the ancient city of Jerusalem. You will then be dropped off at your luxurious accommodation in the heart of the city, and you will be absolutely delighted by the old-world charm that is imbued in the cobblestoned streets. Once you have had time to settle in, you will meet your private tour guide in the hotel lobby for your first introduction to Israel! You will be transferred to Jerusalem’s modern New City, which is the main drag of the famous Ben Yehuda Street. Here, you will delight in your first taste of Israeli falafel or shawarma, which is a traditional Middle-Eastern pita pocket that is typically filled with thinly sliced chicken or lamb and then stuffed with Israeli salad, hummus, and various other delectable toppings. Today, you will enjoy this exciting area, listening to live music from street-performing artists and perusing through the charming shops, restaurants, cafes, and bars that abound from it. You can even stop into one of the many artisan shops that sell traditional hand-crafted, religious artifacts to purchase your first souvenirs from the Holy Land.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Discover the Ancient Old City and Privately Tour the Israel Museum
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will wake up to a delicious Israeli breakfast that consists of the typical fruits, cheeses, bread, and vegetables of the region. After breakfast, you will meet your guide in your hotel lobby to begin your day of adventure. Today, you will discover all four religious quarters of this ancient city on a private tour of the Old City. You will have the pleasure of visiting the magnificent Church of the Holy Sepulchre in the Christian Quarter, which is one of Christianity’s holiest sites. From there, you will stroll through the Muslim Quarter, stopping to marvel at the many artisan products and to purchase souvenirs. As you continue along your tour, you will advance deeper into the Old City, and soon enough, you will approach the remarkable Wailing Wall and marvel at its holy grandeur. You can approach the wall and stick your personal, hand-written note between its aching cracks alongside worshippers who have come from near and far to stand beside you in this very place. Once your wonderful tour of the Old City has concluded, you will be transferred to the illustrious Israel Museum for a very unique, private tour. Here, you will witness the recently discovered Dead Sea Scrolls and learn about their fascinating history before being provided with the opportunity to see the Second Temple Model, which depicts Jerusalem as it was before the Great Revolt against Roman Rule.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Delight in the View from the Mount of Olives and Explore the Shuk
dayInfo.description: This morning, after a delicious breakfast at your hotel, you will meet your private tour guide in the lobby to begin your exploration of the city. Your first stop of the day will be to the famed Mount of Olives, where you will have a view of all of Jerusalem. While absorbing the panoramic views of the city, you can catch a glimpse of the glittering gold of the Dome of the Rock in the distance. You immerse yourself in the whitewashed shades of the city and feel the whisper of thousands of years of history as it beckons you to learn more. Next, your guide will transfer you to the world-renowned Jerusalem Shuk, also known as the Mahane Yehuda Market. Here, you will discover the flavors of Israel as you stroll through the bustling aisleways of the winding market and sample fresh fruit, vegetables, breads, and traditional Israeli delicacies from the local vendors. You can also admire the vibrant colors of the abundant spices and taste a piece of delicious chocolate rugelach , which is a crescent-shaped pastry that is filled with chocolate and coated with a sweet, sticky glaze. You can purchase one of these delicious pastries from one of the many bakeries that line this dynamic market.

dayInfo.title: Negev – Ride Camels in the Desert and Glamp in Luxury Beneath Starry Skies
dayInfo.description: Today, you will delight in breakfast at your hotel before meeting your private tour guide for your transfer to the vast and beautiful Negev Desert. Here, you will be provided with the opportunity to ride camels, which was the once-preferred method of desert transportation, and you will meet a local tribe of nomadic Bedouins who have made the Negev their home. Riding through the boundless desert on camel-back, you can appreciate the glorious views of rocky mountains against a clear blue sky. As your magnificent camel bounces you gently up and down, you will begin to admire just how special and magical your vacation has been already. Once your camel ride has concluded, you will return to the Bedouin village, where you will be met with a glass of delicious sweet tea, which is customary of traditional Bedouin hospitality. You will learn about their fascinating culture and traditions before indulging in a fantastic meal that will be accompanied by a wonderful performance of song and dance. Lastly, you will retire to your opulent “glampsite” to spend the night in complete luxury under a sky full of glittering stars. As you watch the sunset from your luxurious, desert accommodation, you can gaze at your partner as you both savor this romantic moment under the beautiful, night sky.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – View the Beauty of Masada at Sunrise and Bathe in the Briny Dead Sea
dayInfo.description: You will begin before dawn today and transfer to the acclaimed Masada Fortress. Ascending to the top of the majestic fortress via cable car, you will arrive just in time to watch the glorious sunrise over the miraculous Dead Sea. You will then spend your morning privately touring Masada and learning of its captivating history from your guide. You will also discover why this fortress has become a symbol of Israeli strength and resilience. Afterward, you will descend from this towering mountain to begin your transfer to the world-famous Dead Sea. You will arrive at one of the many illustrious beaches of the Dead Sea, where you will be provided with a couple’s spa treatment using the region’s natural mineral mud, which is renowned for its natural healing properties. After your spa treatment, you can take a dip in the sea’s briny waters. Once immersed, you can feel yourself floating weightlessly in the calm waters of the salty sea alongside your partner, and you will bask in the lovely sensation of the warm sunlight upon your faces. This will rejuvenate you as you rinse the slippery water from your body, and your skin will be completely smooth to the touch. Once you have had a chance to dry off and properly soak in this wonderfully unique environment, you will be transferred to the city of Eilat.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – Discover Romantic Eilat and Soak Up the Sun at its Beautiful Beaches
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will wake at your luxurious beachfront hotel and spa accommodation in the heart of Eilat, and you will have pristine views of the beautiful Red Sea. You will enjoy breakfast at your hotel before having the day at your leisure, which will allow you a romantic day at the beach. You can also indulge in a relaxing couple’s massage or spa treatment at your lovely hotel, savoring a day of luxury all to yourselves. You can also bathe in the refreshing waters of the Red Sea and delight in complete relaxation of your Mediterranean vacation. On the beach, you can feel the sand between your toes with your cold beverage in hand as you gaze upon the dazzling mountains that rise and border the sea. You can also meander through Eilat’s lovely city, stopping into the charming shops, restaurants, bars, and cafes per your knowledgeable guide’s recommendation. As you sit poolside, you will smile as all your worries fade away and you become entirely at ease and amazed to be lounging in total luxury. In the evening, you will be provided with a wonderful, gourmet meal at one of Eilat’s romantic, seaside restaurants, so you can reflect with your partner on your fantastic journey thus far.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Experience Jaffa and Uncover the Treasures of Tel Aviv's Shuk
dayInfo.description: Today you will wake up to a delightful breakfast in your exquisite hotel before meeting your private tour guide in the lobby. Your day will begin with a transfer to the glittering, metropolitan city of Tel Aviv. Arrive at your luxurious five-star hotel accommodation on the beach and delight in your first taste of this magnificent city. After you have had time to freshen up, meet your guide once again in the hotel lobby and prepare for your transfer to the world-famous Tel Aviv Shuk, also known as Tel Aviv’s Carmel Market. Your guide will offer helpful insight into the market’s history and their personal recommendations for the best booths at which to stop. You will be left at the mouth of the market to enjoy wandering through its bustling aisles at your leisure. As the pleasant aroma of fresh falafel wafts through the air, you will be drawn to a stand at the edge of the market. You can order and savor a bite of the most delicious falafel that you have ever tasted before quenching your thirst with a sip of freshly squeezed orange juice from the neighboring stand. From the Shuk, you will be transferred to the charming Jaffa neighborhood, where you will delight in a private guided tour to uncover its hidden treasures.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Raft down the Jordan River and Explore the Mystical City of Safed
dayInfo.description: This morning after breakfast, you will be taken on a day trip from Tel Aviv to delight in a thrilling day of whitewater rafting along the famed Jordan River. You will need to prepare yourself for this exciting adventure as you are transferred to the river’s edge. You will be absolutely amazed by the stunning scenery of this vast and eclectic country. Though small in size, Israel is home to a variety of different landscapes from the luscious valleys of the Galilee to the arid Negev desert. You will enjoy an exciting day of rafting down the river as your guide takes the time to discuss the history and religious relevance of the site, and after you have had your proper fill of the Jordan River, you will continue to the sacred city of Safed, which is also referred to as Tzfat, or the “Blue City.” The birthplace of the mystical Kabbalah, this enchanting town is located in the hills of the Galilee and is just as charming as it sounds. Here, you will be given the opportunity to learn about the fascinating study of Kabbalah from one of the area’s world-renowned rabbis. As you walk through the quaint streets of Safed, admiring the beautiful blue buildings, you can stop into one of the many boutique art galleries and meet some of the local artists. You will be awestruck by the intricate detail that many of the artists put into their work, and you will truly be delighted by this once-in-a-lifetime experience.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Luxuriate in a Day of Relaxation at Tel Aviv's Gorgeous Beaches
dayInfo.description: Today, you can rise at your leisure and delight in a wonderful breakfast at your hotel as you overlook the Mediterranean Sea. You will have the entire day to explore Tel Aviv on your own from the sandy white beaches to the stylish neighborhoods at the city’s core. Your guide will also provide you with specific locations that will be of interest to you, which will be based around your interests and what you have found the most fascinating thus far. Your private driver will be available to you throughout the day and will be ready to transfer you at any time. As you walk along the beach promenade, you can take pleasure in watching the endless games of paddleball that are played by locals and tourists, which will create an exciting mixture of languages that will be spoken all around you. You can stop at one of the many beach bars for a cold beverage and traditional, Israeli snack of watermelon and feta cheese as you soak in the gorgeous scenery. Later on, you will discover the trendy Neve Tzedek neighborhood and enjoy the various shops, boutiques, restaurants, and cocktail bars that make this area a must-see when visiting Tel Aviv. Tonight, you will enjoy dinner at one of the area’s most upscale restaurants where you will culminate your final night in this glorious city.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Enjoy Your Final Morning in Tel Aviv and Depart for Home
dayInfo.description: This morning will be your final day in Israel. After breakfast at the hotel, you can spend your remaining hours of walking along the beach or taking a final stroll through the Carmel Market. As you sit down with your companion at a cafe along one of Tel Aviv’s charming side streets, you cannot help but begin to reminisce on your journey through the Holy Land. You will be thinking that this was truly the trip of a lifetime and you would not have wanted to spend it with anyone else. You will return to your hotel to collect your things, and your transfer will escort you to the airport for your flight home.

tourName: The Holy Land Exploration: An Off the Beaten Path Tour of Israel
placesVisited: Jerusalem, Negev Desert, Eilat, Safed, Tel Aviv, Dead Sea
generalInfo: On this historically imbued 10-day tour of Israel, you will explore the Holy Land from a completely new perspective and will discover its most off-the-beaten-path treasures. Walk through the timeworn streets of Jerusalem’s Mea Shearim neighborhood, uncover the ancient secrets of the Cave of the Patriarchs, traverse the streets of Israel’s controversial West Bank, and explore Judaism’s mystical Kabbalah a. From elusive blue grottoes in the north to the vast Negev Desert in the south, Israel is full of secrets that are waiting to be uncovered.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Explore the Mea Shearim Area
dayInfo.description: You will arrive at Ben Gurion Airport, where you will be met at baggage claim by your personal driver. Upon arriving at your luxurious accommodation that is ideally situated in the heart of the city, your guide will allow you to settle in and freshen up before meeting you in the lobby when you are ready. From here, you will be transferred to one of Jerusalem’s most unique and oldest neighborhoods: Mea Shearim. Dressing modestly or conservatively is required because Mea Shearim is home to Israel’s ultra-orthodox Jewish sect.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Visit the Cave of the Patriarchs
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will wake up to enjoy a delicious Israeli breakfast of regional breads, cheeses, vegetables, and fruits at your hotel before meeting your knowledgeable guide in the lobby to begin the day’s activities. Today, you will have the opportunity to explore Jerusalem’s Old City from below as you privately tour the archaic walkways of the Western Wall Tunnels and Zedekiah’s Cave, which are the remains of a 2,000-year-old Jewish city. Afterward, a transfer will convey you to the city of Hebron in the heart of Israel’s controversial West Bank. Here, you can tour the Cave of the Patriarchs, which is one of the most important religious sites for Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

dayInfo.title: Negev – Glamping Beneath the Stars
dayInfo.description: Today, you will wake up before dawn and meet your private tour guide in the lobby for your transfer to the illustrious Masada Fortress, where you will have the opportunity to ascend to the top of the fortress just in time to watch the sunrise over the Dead Sea. Once finished, your descent will mark the beginning of your journey to the Negev Desert. Once among the desert’s vast and rugged landscape, you will be greeted to the Negev by a traditional Bedouin tribe. Riding camels will be a primary highlight of your time here as it is the traditional method of desert transportation. Afterward, you will enjoy a delicious Bedouin meal that is accompanied by typical music and dance.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – Swim in the Dead Sea
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy a Bedouin breakfast before meeting your private guide for your transfer to the world-famous Dead Sea. You will be able to feel completely weightless as you float in the buoyant waters of the sea. Renowned for its healing properties, you will have the opportunity to cover yourself in the region’s famed mineral mud and delight in a luxurious spa treatment. Once you have had your fill of the Dead Sea, your private driver will transfer you to Eilat to enjoy the rest of the day exploring the city’s wonderful beaches, restaurants, and shops.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – Relax at Eilat’s Picturesque Beach
dayInfo.description: This morning, after breakfast, you transfer to the stunning and lesser-known Ein Gedi, which is a serene oasis and nature reserve. Here, you will have the opportunity to trek through the remarkable greenery and to enjoy the many waterfalls. You will even stop to marvel at the juxtaposition of the oasis against the backdrop of the dry Israeli desert. Your guide will point out notable flora and fauna in addition to providing you with the chance to cool off in the refreshing rivers and streams that abound in Ein Gedi. A return transfer to Eilat will allow you to spend the rest of the day at your leisure. You can enjoy the fantastic beaches and relaxed town, or take a nap back in your room.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Discover Mystical Kabbalah
dayInfo.description: After you enjoy your final breakfast at your hotel in Eilat, you will head to the mystical city of Safed. Upon your arrival in Safed, which is also known as Tzfat and the Blue City, your driver will leave you at your luxurious accommodation in the heart of the charming Artist Colony. Once you are ready, you will meet your guide for a private tour of the city, which is famed for being home to the mystical study of Kabbalah. From Safed, you will be transferred to Israel’s West coast to explore the gorgeous Rosh Hanikra grottoes. The steepest cable car in the world is sure to thrill and exhilarate as you slowly descend to the stunning grottoes that overlook Israel’s border with Lebanon.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Tour Haifa’s Baha’i Gardens
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy breakfast and the views of the charming landscape that surrounds you. Your private guide will meet you in the lobby to begin the day’s activities, which will include a transfer to the distinguished city of Haifa. Here, a pirate tour of the Baha’i gardens that overlook the entire city and the sparkling sea will amaze you. Your guide will explain a bit about the Baha’i culture and religion before you make your final descent to the base of the gardens, where you will discover Haifa’s enchanting German Colony. Here, you will have the opportunity to stroll through the streets at your leisure, stopping into the various local shops and restaurants that are recommended to you by your guide. From Haifa, you will enjoy a short ride to the traditional Druze village of Isfiya. Here, you will join a local family for a homemade lunch in their private home.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Traverse the Golan Heights
dayInfo.description: Today, after breakfast, you will meet your guide in the lobby to embark on a full day’s tour to the illustrious Golan Heights. Eventually, you will arrive at Mt. Bental, which is a marvelous overlook near Syria’s border that offers fantastic views of the Golan. Afterward, you will indulge in an exhilarating ATV ride through the vast and rugged landscape of the Golan to one of the region’s finest wineries. Upon your arrival, you will delight in a private tour of the vineyard and winery, where you will learn about the secrets of world-famous, Israeli wine.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Tel Aviv’s Trendiest Neighborhoods
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will awaken for your final breakfast in Safed before meeting your guide in the lobby for your transfer to the metropolitan city of Tel Aviv. You will be dropped off at your magnificent upscale hotel in a prime, beachfront location and will meet your guide in the hotel lobby for your private tour of the city’s trendiest neighborhoods. From here, your guide will lead you to the heart of the city, where you will find Tel Aviv’s infamous Shuk. Once your city tour concludes, you will be left to spend the rest of the afternoon at your leisure, luxuriating in a day at Tel Aviv’s stunning beaches or strolling along the sunny promenade.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Uncover the Secrets of Jaffa
dayInfo.description: Today you will wake up to your final breakfast in Tel Aviv before meeting your guide in the lobby for the last time. You will be transferred to Tel Aviv’s intriguing Jaffa neighborhood to enjoy the morning of strolling through the cobblestone streets and discovering the hidden gems of the famed Jaffa Flea Market. Once your tour concludes, your guide will return you to your hotel to enjoy your final hours in this glistening city. You will return to your hotel to gather your things and meet your driver in the lobby for your private airport transfer home.

tourName: Then and Now: Israel at a Glance in 10 Days
placesVisited: Tel Aviv, Jaffa, Akko, Caesarea National Park, Golan Heights, Galilee, Jordan Valley, Jerusalem, Judean Desert
generalInfo: Travel through time as you explore ancient ruins and vibrant contemporary life on your 10-day Israel hidden-gems tour. Immerse yourself in the ancient splendor of Jerusalem's old-city streets before enjoying the vibrant art and music scene of present-day Tel Aviv. Then, break away from the action for peaceful respite wading in the Dead Sea, touring a picturesque winery, and trekking across rugged terrain in search of cascading waterfalls.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv - Arrival in Israel's Bustling City of Arts and Culture
dayInfo.description: Catch glimpses of the shimmering Mediterranean Sea as you touch down in Israel's coastal city of Tel Aviv. After boarding your complimentary airport transfer you'll zig-zag through the buzzing frenzy of Tel Aviv's music and arts scene downtown as aromas of salt water linger in the air. Spend the afternoon relaxing at the hotel before partaking in a leisurely evening and dinner nearby.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv - Behind the Scenes of Israel's Peace and Defense Efforts
dayInfo.description: The next day you'll explore the quaint port city of Jaffa. Stroll along the water's edge as you watch merchants fill teetering sailboats with fresh produce and other local goods for sale. Then, tantalize your taste buds as you take in the intoxicating aromas of spices, nuts, and bourekas lining the city streets at the popular Levinsky Market. After indulging in an early-afternoon lunch, you'll stroll the storied halls of the Palmach Museum for an up-close look at the underground Haganah defense organization, which was later integrated into the Israel Defense Force and a symbol of Israel's unwavering might.

dayInfo.title: Caesarea National Park - A Skyhigh View of Spectacular Landscapes
dayInfo.description: Journey back in time as you unearth the ancient city of Akko. Peer over magnificent stone walls for a glimpse of the blue-green water splashing fervently against the fortified city. Then, stroll along the pathways of Caesarea Maritima ruins as you marvel at some of the most exquisite stone aqueducts in the world. They date back to c. 22–10 or 9 BCE, under the leadership of Herod the Great. Pause for lunch at midday, before boarding the Rosh HaNikra cable car. There, suspended above majestic rock formations, you'll take in breathtaking views of the spectacular grottos and sparkling blue waters below.

dayInfo.title: Golan Heights - Jeep Trekking and an Illustrious Winery Tour
dayInfo.description: In the morning, take the rugged back roads through Banias Nature Reserve as you explore the ancient Cave of Pan and dip your toes into the refreshing spring waters trickling below. Enjoy lunch on your own, before exploring the lush terrain on four wheels as part of your private Jeep tour. With eyes wide open, you'll catch fleeting views of lush vegetation, stoney cliff sides, and crashing waterfalls. In the afternoon you'll visit one of the region's most renowned wineries. Sip your glass of ruby red as you look out over the illustrious countryside. Dinner is included.

dayInfo.title: Jordan Valley - A Riveting History of Biblical Proportions
dayInfo.description: Creeds around the world trace their origins back to present-day Israel. Discover such historically and biblically significant places as Beit She'an and feel the swift desert breeze on your skin as you look over vistas along the Jordan River Valley. Later, make your way to Sde Eliyahu, a kibbutz in northern Israel, once a refuge for Jews escaping Nazi Germany in the late 1930s; today, a symbol of tight-knit Jewish communities. Lunch is included, followed by an exciting camel excursion that’s sure to delight. In the evening, enjoy dinner at your own pace before returning to your hotel.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem - The Old City and its Diverse Ethnic Origins
dayInfo.description: Past and present, Israel is home to diverse ethnic groups and religious backgrounds. What better way to experience this than up close, on the streets of Jerusalem's Old City. You'll tour the architecture and rich history of Jerusalem's Muslim Quarter and Christian Quarter. Peer up at Temple Mount and David's Tower, before crossing the threshold of Dung Gate to offer prayers, or simply stand in awe opposite the looming Western Wall. Then, in the afternoon, set out on foot once again to uncover gems hidden within the walls of the Armenian and Jewish quarters.

dayInfo.title: Judean Desert - Floating in the Dead Sea and Chasing Waterfalls
dayInfo.description: The following day, just after sunrise, but before the heat settles in, your time travel continues as you summit Masada, an ancient mountaintop fortress located in southeastern Israel. The site of the Jews' final stronghold against the Romans in 70 CE, Masada was designated a World Heritage site in 2001. Take a break from all of the action with a mid-morning respite as you float atop the tranquil waters of the Dead Sea. Enjoy a light lunch before arriving at the Ein Gedi Nature Reserve, where you'll snap pictures of captivating rock formations and iridescent waterfalls.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem - Ancient Relics and Holocaust Remembrance
dayInfo.description: Travel to the City of David to explore the ancient Hezekiah's Tunnel. As far back as the late 8th- and early 7th-century BC, the people of Jerusalem fought for access to the waterway and, ultimately, the city itself. Today, visitors stand in awe of the meticulous stone carvings, now considered one of the greatest water engineering technologies in history. In the afternoon you'll go to the Israel Museum, an art, and archeological museum in Jerusalem, where you can explore colorful ancient pottery and experimental modern art that’s open to interpretation.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem - You Lead the Way: Self-Guided City Exploration
dayInfo.description: Take advantage of your last full day in Israel. You also have the option of one of several free theme days, including Culinary and Wine, Israel Defense Forces, and The Modern State. As part of the Best of Israel: Culinary and Wine Tour, you'll have the unique opportunity to eat and drink your way through the country's finest cuisine, including citrusy seafood in Tel Aviv and mouth-watering Mediterranean treats of tomato and fresh herbs in the lush Galilee Region. In the evening, indulge in Jerusalem's decadent desserts before resting up for the next day's adventure.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem - Souvenir Shopping and Departure
dayInfo.description: Rise and shine as you make the most of your last morning in Israel. Enjoy a leisurely breakfast, then spend the late morning hours relaxing at the hotel, going on one final stroll along the Old City's streets or shopping for souvenirs for family and friends back home. Before long your complimentary airport transfer will arrive to take you to the airport.

placesVisited: Tel Aviv, Haifa, Safed, Negev Desert, Eilat, Jerusalem, Dead Sea
generalInfo: On this 14-day journey through Israel, experience much of the best that this culturally and historically rich country has to offer. From the lively streets of Tel Aviv to the vast desert mountains of the Negev, Israel is a country that is laden with ancient history and modern comforts. Stroll through Jerusalem’s vibrant market, sample a piece of handmade baklava, and float weightlessly in the waters of the Dead Sea. You can even wander through the winding, cobblestoned streets of Jerusalem’s Old City while memories of its ancient past whisper in your ear.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Explore Trendy Neighborhoods
dayInfo.description: To begin your adventure, your private guide will meet you at the Tel Aviv airport. Once you have collected all of your belongings, you will be transferred to your luxurious accommodation that overlooks the Mediterranean Sea. You will spend your first evening in the city, sampling some of the country’s finest cuisine. You will also be guided to Tel Aviv’s trendy Neve Tzedek neighborhood, which is known for its art galleries, boutiques, design shops, high-end music bars, and restaurants. You will have time to explore this upscale area at your leisure.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Private Tour of Tel Aviv
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy your first Israeli breakfast before embarking on an exciting tour of Tel Aviv’s most illustrious sites and neighborhoods. Your tour will begin on Nahalat Binyamin Street, where you will be enchanted by the variety of handicrafts and products that are sold by local artisans. From there, you will continue to the Carmel Market, where you will be guided through the market’s wonderful stalls full of traditional Israeli products. In the afternoon, you will be led to the beach, where you can spend the afternoon at your leisure, strolling along the sunny promenade and basking in the sun.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – The Jaffa Flea Market
dayInfo.description: Today, you will be transferred to Tel Aviv’s infamous Jaffa neighborhood. Your private tour will begin at the Jaffa Clock Tower, which is an important monument that was built during the Ottoman Rule. After lunch, you will be led to the Jaffa Flea Market. Alive with the exciting buzz of bargaining and traditional haggling, the market will throw you into action. From the flea market, you will be guided to one of Jaffa’s higher-end neighborhoods, where you can meander through upscale art galleries, boutiques, and shops to appreciate the unique, artistic style of the area.

dayInfo.title: Haifa – Dine with a Local Druze Family
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy an Israeli breakfast before transferring to your luxurious accommodation in the nearby port city of Haifa. Upon your arrival, you will have a moment to settle in before meeting your expert guide to embark on the day’s activities. You will begin your tour with an exclusive visit to Haifa’s Baha’i gardens. At the base of the gardens, you will arrive in the German Colony of the city, where you will have the opportunity to stroll through its enchanting streets, stopping into the lovely shops and cafes at your leisure. In the afternoon, you will be transferred to the nearby Druze village of Isfiya, where you will be provided with the unique opportunity to enjoy lunch in the home of a local Druze family.

dayInfo.title: Haifa – Visit an Israeli Kibbutz
dayInfo.description: Today, you will enjoy breakfast at your hotel before being transferred to Kibbutz Ein Gev. Israeli Kibbutzim are communal settlements that were originally focused on agricultural pursuits but have now expanded to various other fields. During your visit, you will be provided with the unique opportunity to visit one of the largest and wealthiest of Israel’s kibbutzim. In the afternoon, you will return to Haifa, where you will spend the remainder of the day relaxing at Carmel Beach. At the beach, you can bask in the sun and relax on the white sand. You may elect to partake in water sports, such as windsurfing, surfing, or parasailing.

dayInfo.title: Safed – Explore the Blue City
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will have breakfast at your hotel before transferring to Safed. You will arrive at your luxurious accommodation in the heart of the Artist Quarter. Known as Israel’s infamous Blue City and the birthplace of the mystical Jewish study of Kabbalah, Safed will blow you away with all that the amazing city has to offer. After you have had time to settle in to your suite, you will meet your guide to begin your exploration of Safed. In the evening, you will be transferred to the home of a local Jewish family, where you will enjoy a traditional Shabbat dinner.

dayInfo.title: Safed – One of the Golan’s Finest Wineries
dayInfo.description: Today, you will enjoy breakfast at your hotel before meeting your guide in the lobby to explore the Golan Heights. You will be transferred to the peak of Mt. Bental, which is a remarkable lookout point from Israel into Syria. After you have time to admire the views from Mt. Bental, you will be transferred to one of the region’s finest wineries, where you will learn about Israel’s winemaking industry in addition to having the opportunity to sample some of the country’s finest vintages. In the afternoon, you will be transferred to the Sea of Galilee. During your visit, you will have the opportunity to bathe in the sea and to relax on its scenic shores.

dayInfo.title: Negev – Dead Sea and Masada Fortress
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will eat a light breakfast before transferring to the Masada fortress. You will arrive at Masada and ascend to the top of the fortress in time to watch the sunrise over the Dead Sea. Once it begins to warm, you will descend from Masada via cable car before joining your private driver for a short transfer to the Dead Sea. You will spend the next several hours delighting in this natural phenomenon as you float in the sea’s briny waters and cover yourself in natural mineral mud. When you are ready, you will be met by a local Bedouin tribe. You will be welcomed with traditional Bedouin tea and delicacies as you are invited into a tent to experience their unique culture and hear about their customs and practices.

dayInfo.title: Negev – Encounters with a Bedouin Tribe
dayInfo.description: Today, you will embark on an exciting desert trek. During your time in the desert, you will be provided with the wonderful opportunity to ride a camel, which is the traditional form of desert transportation. When you begin to work up an appetite, you will enjoy lunch at your glampsite, where you will then have the opportunity to wander through the Bedouin village. In the evening, you will attend a traditional dinner that will be accompanied by a Bedouin performance of song and dance. During the performance, you will sit cross-legged on colorful cushions and bask in the beauty of the spellbinding movements.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – The Shores of the Red Sea
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy your final breakfast in the Negev before transferring to the seaside city of Eilat. You will arrive at your beachfront resort in Eilat. After you have had ample opportunity to settle in to your luxurious suite, you will meet your guide for a quick tour of the area. After your tour, you can spend the day luxuriating on the shores of the Red Sea, basking in the sun, and relaxing in complete comfort. As the day presses on, you may elect to swim with dolphins on a several-hour excursion, which can be organized for you by your guide. You may also choose to partake in scuba diving or snorkeling at Eilat’s infamous Coral Beach.

dayInfo.title: Eilat – The Natural Oasis of Ein Gedi
dayInfo.description: Today, you be transferred to the natural oasis of Ein Gedi, where you will spend the morning on a leisurely hike to one of Israel’s most impressive waterfalls. After you have had your fill of Ein Gedi, you will be returned to Eilat, where you will enjoy lunch in the city before spending the remainder of the afternoon at your leisure, relaxing at the gorgeous beaches. You may also decide to indulge in a luxurious spa treatment at your beachfront resort or to delight in a refreshing snack or beverage at one of the many seaside bars and cafes.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Discover the Lively New City
dayInfo.description: This morning, you will enjoy your final breakfast in Eilat before transferring to Jerusalem. As you arrive at your luxurious accommodation in the heart of the city, you will settle in to your extravagant suite before meeting your guide to begin your exploration of Jerusalem. You will begin with a transfer to the magnificent Mount of Olives. From the Mount of Olives, you will be transferred to Mahane Yehuda Market, where you will have the opportunity to indulge in Jerusalem’s finest delicacies from a variety of local vendors. After the market, you will visit the rest of Jerusalem’s modern New City.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Treasures of the Old City
dayInfo.description: Today, you will enjoy an Israeli breakfast at your hotel before meeting your experienced guide to begin your busy day of touring and exploring Jerusalem. You will begin your tour with a transfer to Jerusalem’s Old City, where you will be transported through history as you traverse the cobblestoned streets and winding alleyways. During your tour, you will visit the city’s most noteworthy destinations and will begin at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, which is one of Christianity’s holiest sites. After your tour of the Old City has concluded, you will be transferred to the illustrious Yad Vashem, which is the World Holocaust Remembrance Center.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Departure
dayInfo.description: Today you rise to your final day in Israel. After enjoying your final breakfast in Israel, you can spend the morning as you please, strolling through the winding streets of the city or stopping into a coffee shop on Ben Yehuda Street. As you gaze upon the influx of tourists and locals, you may begin to reminisce on your incredible journey thus far. Soon after, you will return to your hotel for your transfer to the airport. Once you are at the airport, you will be led to your terminal for your international flight home.

generalInfo: The exotic spices of Israeli cuisine fill streets and surrounding landscapes with enticing aromas during your customizable culinary tour. Uncover the secrets to seductive baklava and decadent rugelach. The Mediterranean Sea gives way to the vineyards and orchards of Galilee. Cobblestone lanes contain celebrated restaurants. Spice markets radiate with color, and the scent of rich coffee lingers in the air. Whether a self-professed foodie celebrating international flavors or a home chef eager to learn a new style of cooking, your time in Israel will demonstrate the fascinating effect that culture and history have on the developing flavors of regional gastronomy.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem - Israel at First Taste
dayInfo.description: Jerusalem overtakes the desert hills and shimmers with creamy antique stones and celebrated gilded domes. Olive orchards and cypress trees absorb water from underground springs. Cobblestone streets wind between ancient buildings, leading to the remnants of ancient Roman and Byzantine roads. Locals wander through the aisles of the Mahane Yehuda Market, basking in the dynamic culinary scene of produce vendors and restaurants serving a mixture of classic Israeli cuisine and contemporary twists on Middle Eastern culture. Your flight lands at Ben Gurion International Airport. Your private transfer greets you upon your arrival and escorts you to the enchanting city of Jerusalem. Your luxurious hotel overlooks the ancient walls of the city, offering a mixture of historical charm with contemporary comfort. The remainder of the day is yours to wander through the enticing aromas and fascinating architecture of the city. For an introduction into Jerusalem, you make your way to the Tower of David, located on a promontory overlooking the Old City. The palace of Herod the Great once stood atop the citadel, followed by the occupations of the Romans and keen Crusaders. The citadel now holds the dramatic galleries of the Museum of the History of Jerusalem, which offers a chronological telling of the city’s past from the second millennium BCE up to the founding of Israel in 1948. A chiseled block from one of Herod’s lesser towers continues to stand at the base of the main keep, and the 16th-century gate greets visitors at the entrance to the citadel. The hill provides the perfect sampling of Israel’s remarkable history, which has influenced the cuisine over time.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – A Day’s Worth of Samples
dayInfo.description: The morning sun washes over Jerusalem, returning the creamy hues to the stone. The gilded cupola adorning the Dome of the Rock glints in the returning light. Houses erected during the reign of Herod the Great reflect the lifestyles of Jerusalem in the 1st centuries BCE and CE. Mosaic flooring represents the lavish décor of the city’s patrons, alongside decorative frescoes and remaining pillars. Your guide meets you at the hotel after breakfast, eager to lead you through the aisles of the Mahane Yehuda Market. Your guide is also a chef familiar with the cuisine of Jerusalem and the Middle East. He leads you along the bustling marketplace filled with gregarious vendors calling out to passersby. Pomegranates shimmer with purple and red hues. The scent of fresh lemons accompanies the bright crimsons and emeralds from the tomato and cucumber salads. You sample tasty olives harvested from local orchards and sweet pistachios often used for garnish. The cover over Etz Chayim Street provides a respite from the desert sun. The various names of the alleyways offer insight into the products available. HaAfarsek stands for “Peach,” letting visitors know they can find the juicy, luscious fruit displayed in the lane. Your guide stops at a pastry stall and speaks with the owner. He hands you a small, flaky rugelach, a pastry of Ashkenazy origin often filled with cinnamon, raisins, or chocolate. The mixture of a buttery, crunchy puff pastry, and bittersweet chocolate is a perfect, portable flavor to accompany you as you wander amongst the display of enticing spices and satisfying produce.

dayInfo.title: Jerusalem – Connecting the Flavors of Jerusalem
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the cafes around the city open their doors and fill the streets with the aroma of strong Arabica coffee. Palm trees rustle their fronds in the sporadic breeze, carrying the scent of dates. After breakfast, your guide meets you in the hotel lobby, excited to take you first to a bakery offering some of the best challah bread in the city and possibly the world. You follow the narrow aisles around the Mahane Yehuda Market once more, following the sweet scent of rising dough. The bakers welcome you with wide arms and friendly smiles, eager to share their trade before offering a sample of the celebrated challah bread. Their sweet bread has a heavy, doughy quality with a satisfying brightness similar to a cake. Your guide says the bakers like to keep the bread flavorful as a celebration of ending the past week and beginning the new week in a sweet way. The metaphor continues into the braiding of the bread, which represents unity and tying the world together. You continue to the Old City, where the aroma of freshly made falafel begins to fill the air. Hidden alleys contain small restaurants hosting scattered tables and chairs. Patrons linger on the outskirts of the restaurants and watch passersby while enjoying fresh hummus and crunchy falafel. Your guide leads you to a tiny establishment renowned for its hummus; it is also the only dish the restaurant serves. The aroma of garlic and parsley swirls over the countertops. Patrons eagerly dip warm pita into the creamy texture swimming with olive oil. You follow your guide’s lead and glide your pita into the dip made of chickpeas and oil, tasting the pure decadent flavor of the popular Middle Eastern dish.

dayInfo.title: Galilee – A Different Side of Israel
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the market returns to its brimming nature, filling with locals eager to find the best deal on tomatoes and artichoke. The cafes along the cobblestones streets of the Old City open their doors to the enticing aroma of fresh coffee drifting out of the antique doorways. Your private transfer meets you at the hotel and escorts you to Galilee and the largest Arab town in the country, Nazareth. Christian mythology places Nazareth as the city of the Archangel Gabriel’s Annunciation. The tranquil and grand Church of the Annunciation was erected in the 1960s over the remnants of a Byzantine church first erected in the 3rd century. Shops line the boulevards and meandering lanes amongst a collection of mansions dating back to the Ottoman Empire. You make your way to a spice shop that has been marketing local and international flavors for more than a century. An exotic array of fragrances wafts through the open door as you enter. The vendors greet you with respect and excitement, delighted to introduce you to their trade. Turmeric shimmers with golden yellow hues and cinnamon provide an unforgettable spiced aroma to the air. Red pepper has a rich color against the muddled, powdery texture of coriander. The back room contains a large, antique machine powered by steam. The instrument processes chickpeas, while the neighboring mechanism roasts coffee, adding to the layered bouquet filling the shop.

dayInfo.title: Galilee – In the Habit of the Countryside
dayInfo.description: In the morning, the Nazareth Market takes visitors back in time to the bazaars of old. Arabian music spills onto the cobblestone walkways. The scent of hummus and bright spices blends with herbaceous incense. Vibrant colors from spice mounds accompany effervescent pinks and yellows of the saris on display. After breakfast, your guide greets you in the hotel lobby and leads you out of the lively city to a local farm growing olive orchards to produce decadent olive oil. The scenic ride takes you along date palms and the glittering waters of the Sea of Galilee. Wildflowers blossom with yellow and pink petals against the verdant plains. Hot springs steam into the air and vineyards sweep across the landscape, offering insight into millennia of epicurean delights. You reach the farm and enjoy a view of the swath of emerald hills bordering the horizon. The image of desert scenery escapes you, replaced by the feeling of seemingly being in Tuscany or the south of France. The semi-sweet scent of the olive orchards sweeps in with the breeze. Your guide leads you along the trails around the trees, pointing out the colors of the olives dangling from the trees. Citrus groves grow near the olives, creating lush and bright fragrances to accompany the olives. The statehouse contains a sampling room offering a view of the surrounding landscape. You have a brief introduction to the historical versus the contemporary ways of pressing the olives before sampling the oil produced on the plantation. A simple sip of the olive oil offers a creamy, pure texture coating your palate, accompanied by a burst of umami.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – History with Flavor
dayInfo.description: The history of Galilee spreads beyond the streets of Nazareth, displayed in the small Kibbutz of Ginosar Yigal Alon. The center exhibits the remains of a wooden boat crafted two millennia ago. The vessel reaches a length of 26.5 feet and was constructed with a variety of recycled woods. After breakfast, your guide takes you to a Druze Village outside of Tel Aviv for a hands-on cooking lesson and introduction to the Druze culture. The religious and ethnic minority incorporates elements of Islam, Gnosticism, and spiritual philosophies. Your instructor welcomes you into her home, eager to introduce you to the flavors of Druze cuisine. You sip a tiny cup of fragrant mint tea or cinnamon coffee. Your host provides a sampling of sweets, which turn out to be candied squash. You help create a flat, round dough before slipping it into a brick kiln that quickly bakes the sesame cake. From the back window, you find the Galilee landscape spreading to the horizon with fertile hills and valleys. Your instructor helps you craft and fold crescent-shaped dumplings, stuffing the dough with soft cheese. The scent of crispy, butter dumplings quickly fills the kitchen with a mouthwatering effect. You bite into the entrée, listening to the crunch and tasting the savory melting cheese. You continue to the ancient port of Akko, where Marco Polo once passed through nearly eight centuries ago en route to China.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – The Scents of the City
dayInfo.description: In the morning, fishing boats weigh anchor and make their way along the Mediterranean. The water shimmers in the spreading sunlight and splashes against the gold sand beaches. A private chef meets you at the hotel, eager to lead you through the fabulous markets of Tel Aviv. Locals make their way to the shoreline and bask in the splendid heat. Cyclists and joggers take to the promenade stretching upwards of nine miles before reaching the antique streets of Old Jaffa. You traverse the walkways of Levinsky Market, which opened in the 1930s after Jewish families arrived from Thessaloniki, Greece. The marketplace specializes in Balkan and Persian cuisine, exhibiting stunning spice stalls and special dishes focusing on the various uses of local nuts. Gourmet restaurants stand beside dried fruit stands, and bakeries offer tastings of crispy baklava smothered in honey. The scent of fresh bread drifts out of a locally celebrated bakery while a range of Turkish spices fills the store of a popular delicatessen. Dried mango and sugared dates provide a sweet scent to the air. After exploring the market stalls, your private chef leads you into the kitchen to learn the secrets of preparing a proper Israeli meal, accented with restaurant quality sophistication.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Beyond the Golden Beaches
dayInfo.description: The history of Israel explains the developed flavors of the cuisine. Today is yours to explore the splendors of Tel Aviv, your favorite dishes of the varied cultures of Israel, and the beachside chic of the city at your preferred pace. The Mediterranean waves lap at the shoreline beneath the sporadic high-rises of the contemporary city. Locals play matkot on the sand, the national sport of Israel, bouncing the ball back and forth with wood paddles. Carmel Market fills with antique architecture and colorful produce, from artichokes to radishes. You make your way to Jaffa to visit one of the oldest ports along the Mediterranean. The former railway station now holds a series of boutique shops and charming cafes connected to the cobblestone walkways. The sunlight bounces off the antique stone structures overlooking the jetties. Artists capture the beauty of the seaside and charms of daily life through various methods. Masts of moored fishing boats wade in the calm sea and reflect in the turquoise water’s surface. Walk beneath the stone archways and follow the meandering streets amongst the aroma of enticing hummus and delicious shakshuka, eggs poached in a tomato chili sauce, mingling with the scent of the sea. The clock tower was erected in the early 1900s and continues to rise above the antique streets of the city, representing one of the major landmarks of the historical city.

dayInfo.title: Tel Aviv – Lingering Tastes in Tel Aviv
dayInfo.description: The lush greenery of Yarkon Park beckons to the locals of Tel Aviv. Families cast fishing lines into the lakes and thrill seekers climb the artificial rock wall. The Yarkon River travels through the park and filters into the Mediterranean Sea after more than 17 miles. Restaurants throughout the city open their doors to the aroma of simmering shakshuka and freshly brewed Arabica coffee. Juiceries make freshly pressed juices from vibrant produce bought earlier that morning at the Carmel Market. Your private transfer meets you at the hotel when you are ready, and escorts you to Ben Gurion International Airport for your flight home.
